{{Infobox |name = |bodystyle = |title = [[Basketball playbook]] |titlestyle = |image = [[File:Basketball Defense 2-3 Zone.svg|250px]] |imagestyle = |caption = 2–3 zone initial alignment |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ffa500; |labelstyle = background:#ddf; |datastyle = "float: left;" |header10 = 2–3 zone Defense |label10 = |data10 = |header20 = |label20 = Type: |data20 = Half court zone defense |header30 = Name Usage |label30 = |data30 = |header31 = |label31 = Technical name: |data31 = 2–3 zone Defense |label32 = Common name: |data32 = 2–3 zone |label33 = Other common names: |data33 = 2–1–2 zone |header40 = Play Development Credit |label40 = |data40 = |header41 = |label41 = Designed 1st by: |data41 = Coach [[Cam Henderson]] |label42 = Year play 1st used: |data42 = 1914 |label46 = Play 1st used by: |data46 = Bristol high school |label47 = Country: |data47 = United States }}
The '''2–3 zone defense''' is a defensive strategy used in basketball as an alternative to [[man-to-man defense]]. It is referred to as the 2–3 because of its formation on the court, which consists of two players at the front of the defense (and closer to half court) and three players behind (and closer to the team's basket).
==History == In 1914, [[Cam Henderson|Eli Camden "Cam" Henderson]]'s Bristol High School first used a 3-2 zone defense against [[Clair Bee]]'s team, Grafton YMCA, in West Virginia. The zone defense was used because the gym floor was made of green pine and it was very slippery when wet, when the roof leaked.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=DDO3sdV6ytsC&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=eli+camden+henderson&source=bl&ots=q7Es7yC5PW&sig=l5pRplNjkbJM4wqyut9wQLGxHAI&hl=en&ei=uRBoStCiEIuAsgPdiMiFBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 Basketball by David L. Porter]</ref>
The [[3-2 zone defense]] did not provide the rebounding support for the [[fast break]] that Cam Henderson was using. The top defender dropped back to form the 2–3 zone. Henderson developed this style of basketball successfully at [[Davis & Elkins College]], before moving on to coach at [[Marshall Thundering Herd men's basketball|Marshall University]].
In 1938, Marshall University upset [[LIU Brooklyn Blackbirds men's basketball|Long Island University]], to snap their 40-game winning streak.<ref>Coach Don Casey & Ralph Pim, Own the Zone – Executing & attacking the zone defense, New York: McGraw Hill, 2008, p. 18</ref>
In 1947, Henderson led Marshall to a [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA) championship title with his 2–3 zone defense and [[fast break]] offense.<ref>Coach Don Casey & Ralph Pim, Own the Zone – Executing & attacking the zone defense by Charlie Halford New York: McGraw Hill, 2008, p. 19</ref>
In [[2002–03 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|2003]], [[Syracuse Orange men's basketball|Syracuse University]] coach [[Jim Boeheim]] led his [[2002–03 Syracuse Orangemen basketball team|team]] to an [[2003 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] championship playing the 2-3 zone, which has become Boeheim's trademark.
==How to play a 2–3 zone defense== The widespread use of the 2–3 zone is likely due to its somewhat intuitive operation. The two players on the top of the zone are usually a team's guards, and they guard the zones closest to them on the perimeter and three-point arc. In the same way, a team's forwards guard the sides of the zone and its center guards the lane and center of the defense. As the opposing team moves with the basketball around the court, the ''zone as a whole'' shifts accordingly.
The individuals that make up a 2–3 zone are often described as "being on a string." This means that as one player moves, he pulls the imaginary string (which is attached to every defensive player) and therefore pulls the entire defense in that same direction. As the ball moves throughout the court, every player should shift simultaneously in the direction of the ball. When a player in the zone is shifting, that player should look to fill in gaps of space vacated by other shifting players and also guard offensive players in that space.
For example, if a player with the ball stood on the right wing (beyond the three point arc), defensive players 1 and 2 would shift towards that direction. To effectively operate the 2–3 zone, a defense must move as a whole. In this case, that would mean every defensive player shifting around 5 to 6 feet in the direction of the right wing and the player with the ball. Similarly, if that player moved to the right corner, the 4 player would move to guard him and the rest of the defense would shift towards that direction. So much so, in fact, that ideally no defensive players should be on the left side of the court at all, because it would require several passes, or a long pass(skip pass) through the defense to get the ball to the left side.
===Key points of emphasis=== *''Communicate'' — this is probably the most important thing to remember when playing a 2–3 zone. Players should talk to each other on the court about who's open, who should be where, what to do, and everything else worth knowing. The team must work together, and the best way to do so is to communicate with each other on the floor. *Players should anticipate the next pass before it happens, so that when it does, each person knows where to go on the floor and fewer breakdowns happen. *Although it is a zone defense, players should always be aware of the offensive players' locations on the floor. It is more important to guard an open player than stay within the normal constraints of the zone. *Offensive players closer to the basket take priority. The defense begins at the basket and radiates outwards—the idea is to force the offense to take shots from the perimeter and prevent access to the basket and surrounding area.
==Strengths of the 2–3 zone== The 2–3 zone is a very effective defense when executed properly. This defense's strong suits include:
*Forcing outside shots—it generally holds true that as players get further away from the basket, their chances of scoring decrease. The 2–3 essentially fills the middle of the court and is very effective at preventing penetration into the lane and heart of the defense, leaving the perimeter as an offense's most accessible option. *"Hiding" poor defensive players—because the 2–3 zone is so team-oriented, players who are less effective defensively are less likely to be exploited by the offense. It is very difficult to target just one defensive player in the 2–3 because the zone is always shifting and players work together. Similarly, using a 2–3 more evenly distributes fouls throughout the players on defense, meaning foul-prone players are less likely to accumulate many fouls or foul out. *Slowing the game (Gibson)—Because the 2–3 often guards the interior of the court well, offenses generally pass the ball around the perimeter frequently before attempting to penetrate the defense or initiate an offense. As a result, it takes longer for an offense to take a shot, and therefore slows the tempo of the game. Therefore, hypothetically defensive players have more time to catch their breath as a result. Also players exert somewhat less energy in a zone than in man-to-man since they often cover less ground while playing defense. *Fewer offensive plays—There are far fewer zone offenses than there are man-to-man offenses to prepare for as a defense. As a result, defenses often have a better idea of what to expect from the offensive team when playing a zone defense.<ref>http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/ncaatourney03/story?id=1532389</ref>
==Weaknesses of the 2–3 zone== On the other hand, there are many reasons why many coaches prefer not to use the zone. Its strengths can easily become its weaknesses, which include:
*Perimeter scoring—because the 2–3 zone often leaves some parts of the perimeter wide open for the opposing offense's long-range shooters, offenses that excel at 3-point shots and mid-range jump shots always have a chance to keep the score even (or, to build large leads). This is probably the 2–3's most obvious Achilles' heel. *Playing from behind—teams that are losing rarely use the 2-3 zone, because it gives the opposing offense ample time—and space—to repeatedly pass the ball around the perimeter, reducing the amount of time left in the game. *Rebounding—in man-to-man defense, defensive players know who to "block out" if the shot misses, and an offensive rebound's attempted; each defender covers the individual offensive player they're assigned to personally defend. However, in the 2–3 zone, defensive players do not guard individuals, only areas of the court (zones); so, it is more difficult to quickly and accurately assess where the offensive players are, and which defensive players are supposed to block them out. As a result, 2–3 zones often yield more rebounds for the opposing offense, which can tire out a defense, and/or put them far behind in scoring. *Gaps in the zone—there are a few areas on the court that often cause breakdowns in the 2–3 zone, especially at the high-[[post (basketball)|post]] area. The high post/[[free throw]] line area (i.e., the center of the 2–3 zone) is often a weak spot in the zone that is exploited by the offense. Multiple defensive players tend to "collapse" (i.e., converge at once) on an offensive player who has the ball in this part of the zone, leaving other offensive players unguarded on the wings, blocks, and/or baseline areas. *Degree of difficulty—because the 2–3 zone relies so heavily on well-timed teamwork, each individual player must know exactly where to be at all times. Because a zone defense is more complex than simply following one player always following his counterpart around the court, there is a higher probability that at least one defensive player will forget which opposing player he/she was assigned to guard. Players must be extremely practiced and knowledgeable to run a 2–3 zone correctly.
==Notes== *The 2–3 zone is sometimes called a 2–1–2 zone, simply because the player (usually the center) standing under the basket moves further up on the key. The concept, however, remains the same. The 2–1–2 concept is used when the other team runs cutters to break down the zone.
== External links == * [http://www.hooptactics.net/freesite/defstrategies/23zone1.php HoopTactics: 2-3 Zone Defense]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

Formed in 1953, AS Manu Ura has a strong history in domestic and regional football with five league titles and three Coupe de Polynesie crowns to their name. ==Recent Seasons== The side has been a dominant force in Tahitian football between 2007 and 2010. The club won a hat-trick of league titles from 2007 to 2009, twice qualifying for the [[OFC Champions League]]. In 2010 the club finished top of the league table however they only managed fifth in the Championship Play-Off resulting in the title and Champions League qualification going to rivals [[AS Tefana]]. ==Achievements== *'''[[Tahiti First Division]]: 5''' :: 1996, 2004, 2007, 2008, 2009. *'''[[Tahiti Cup]]: 2 ''' :: 2003, 2005. *'''[[Tahiti Coupe des Champions]]: 1 ''' :: 2008. *'''[[Coupe T.O.M|Pacific French Territories Cup]]: 2''' :: 1996, 2004. ===Continental Record=== {| class="wikitable" ! revision.text:
{{you|date=January 2017}} [[File:Basse fra Trøndelag.jpeg|thumb|A basse, made of cut bicycle rubber tubes, tied together into a ball. Photo: Lars Haugdal Andersen / www.basse.no]]
'''Basse''' is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] bag ball game, with roots before World War I.<ref>Sørensen, B. (1980). Basse – ein trøndersport. I: Stemshaug, O. (red.) (Yearbook for Trøndelag). Trondheim: Trønderlaget. pp. 119–124.</ref> Today basse is mostly played in the [[county]] of [[Trøndelag]], but also spread to other countries.
==Construction== The basse can be made with rings (two or three, up to eight). Use [[rubber]] band or old bicycle [[Tyre (wheel)|tyre]]. The basse is a bag ball, it should be round, but not bounce in any direction. The weight is about 70 – 100 [[gram]]s.
==Gameplay==
Create fields (squares or circles) on any surface (gravel, tarmac, grass or indoors). Use your feet, chalk or spray paint to create the field, depending on the surface. First, draw the mid field circle. Diameter 1–1,5 metre. Make room, 30–40 cm between the next circles. You can have 4 to 8 fields around the center circle. The optimal number of players are 5–7, but 8–9 can play a game of basse, depending on the field and space available.
The overall goal is to defend your field (a circle) and to score goals on the other players. It is an individual sport and everyone plays against everyone. The game starts with a serve (not lower than the knee). If you concede a goal (i.e. the basse must land completely inside the circle and not touch the edge), you get one minus point. After 3 minus points you are out of the game. You must defend your circle and the players can hit the basse with all body limbs, except arms and hands.
The finale is played when there are two players left. ”The first goal wins”, regardless of the number of minus points each finalists has received before.
Some players practice rules for refereeing, dead squares, hand ball and penalty kicks. Basse tournaments are often held during the summer season.
==See also== * [[Footbag]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.basse.no/basse-in-english/ www.basse.no] in English
{{DEFAULTSORT:Basse (Bag Ball)}} [[Category:Footbag]] [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Football codes]]

{{One source|date=October 2018}} {{coord|36|47|0|S|174|44|39|E|region:NZ_type:landmark |display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Eventfinda Stadium | nickname = | image = | image_size = 250px | fullname = | address = 17 Silverfield Ln
[[Auckland]] 0627
[[New Zealand]] | location = [[Wairau Valley, Auckland|Wairau Valley]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1991 | built = | opened = {{Start date|df=yes|1992|9}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Auckland Council|Regional Facilities Auckland]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]6 million | architect = | former_names = North Shore Events Centre {{small|(1992-2018)}} | tenants = [[New Zealand Breakers]] {{small|([[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL]]) (2003–present)}} | capacity = 4,179 | record_attendance = | dimensions = | scoreboard = | website = {{url|www.eventfindastadium.co.nz|Venue Website}} }} The '''Eventfinda Stadium'''{{cite press release |author= |title=EVENTFINDA TAKES ON NAMING RIGHTS AND TICKETING FOR NORTH SHORE EVENTS CENTRE |url=https://www.ausleisure.com.au/news/eventfinda-takes-on-naming-rights-and-ticketing-for-north-shore-events-centre/ |location=Auckland, New Zealand |publisher=Australasian Leisure Management |agency= |date=12 October 2018 |access-date=21 October 2008}} (originally known as the '''North Shore Events Centre''') is an indoor [[arena]] located in the [[North Shore, New Zealand|North Shore City]] suburb of [[Wairau Valley, Auckland|Wairau Valley]], [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]. The arena opened in 1992 and has a capacity of 4,179.{{cite web |url=http://www.nseventscentre.co.nz/Venue+Information/Seating+Capacities.html |title=Seating Capacities |author= |date=September 2008 |website=North Shore Events Centre |publisher= |access-date=21 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023090541/http://www.nseventscentre.co.nz/Venue+Information/Seating+Capacities.html |archive-date=23 October 2010}} It primarily hosts community events and was the home arena of the [[New Zealand Breakers]], who play in the [[National Basketball League (Australia)|Australasian NBL]]. It also hosts concerts, expos, trade shows, conferences, Netball, MMA, Cheerleading, Dance. It has also hosted the New Zealand Badminton Open for over 10 years. In 2009, the arena hosted the final of the [[2009 FIBA Under-19 World Championship|FIBA Under-19 World Championship]]. The final saw the [[United States men's national basketball team|United States]] defeat [[Greece national basketball team|Greece]] 88-80. ==Boxing== It has hosted a number of fight nights, the majority of them promoted by [[Shane Cameron]]. The most famous fight night was in November 2014 where [[Kali Meehan]] fought Shane Cameron for the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] Pan African Heavyweight Title. Also on the card was the Super 8 Cruiserweight tournament. The event was promoted by John Mcrae and New Zealand Sky Arena, as well as being live on Pay Per View with [[Sky Arena]] in New Zealand and Australia Main event. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = [[FIBA U-19 World Championship]]

[[Novi Sad]] | after = [[Arena Riga]]

{{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = White | color2 = Blue | name = Hatay Büyükşehir Belediye Gençlik ve Spor Kulübü | nickname = | logo = File:Antakya Belediyespor logo.jpg | imagesize = 100px | leagues = [[Turkish Women's Basketball League]] | founded = 2010 | arena = [[Antakya Sport Hall]]
(capacity: 2,500) | location = [[Antakya]]/[[Hatay Province|Hatay]] , [[Turkey]] | colors = Blue and White | president = {{flagicon|Turkey}} Serdar Güven | coach = {{flagicon|Turkey}} Ekin Baş | championships = | website = [http://hataybbspor.com/ hataybbspor.com] |}} '''Hatay Büyükşehir Belediye Women Basketball''' is the women basketball section of [[Hatay Büyükşehir Belediye Gençlik ve Spor Kulübü|Hatay Büyükşehir Belediyespor]], a major [[sports club]] in [[Hatay Province|Hatay]], [[Turkey]]. '''Hatay Büyükşehir Belediyespor''' was founded in 2010 and the team managed to advance to the First League after seven months of its establishment. Currently the team competes in the [[Turkish Women's Basketball League|Turkish Women's Basketball League (TKBL)]]. The team plays their home games at the 2,500-seating capacity [[Antakya Sport Hall]]. ==Previous names== *'''Antakya Belediyesi''' (2010–2012) *'''Homend Antakya Belediye''' (2012–2014) *'''Hatay {{For|the stadium in Lusaka, Zambia|National Heroes Stadium}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Heroes Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[File:Heroes stadium.JPG|300px]] | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = 4799 Thousand Oaks Dr
San Antonio, Texas 78233 | coordinates = {{coord|29.536862|-98.397826|type:landmark|name=Heroes Stadium|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = December 18, 2007 | built = | opened = August 28, 2009 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[North East ISD]] | operator = North East ISD | surface = Fieldturf Duraspine{{cite web|url=http://www.paragon-sports.com/projects.html |title=Projects |publisher=Paragon Sports Constructors |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718174030/http://www.paragon-sports.com/projects.html |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Heroes Stadium Brochure|url=http://www.neisd.net/constr/bonds/projects/heroes_stadium/files/Heroes_Stadium_Brochure.pdf|publisher=North East ISD}} | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = Rehler Vaughn & Koone, Inc. | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Joeris General Contractors, Ltd. | main_contractors = | capacity = 11,122{{cite web|title=Heroes Stadium Inaugural Year|url=http://www.neisd.net/constr/files/Heroes_Stadium_Inaugural_Year.pdf|publisher=North East ISD}} | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = 58 | tenants = [[Winston_Churchill_High_School_(San_Antonio,_Texas)|Churchill High School]]
[[Lady_Bird_Johnson_High_School|Johnson High School]]
[[Lee_High_School_(San_Antonio,_Texas)|Lee High School]]
[[Douglas_MacArthur_High_School_(San_Antonio,_Texas)|MacArthur High School]]
[[James_Madison_High_School_(San_Antonio,_Texas)|Madison High School]]
[[Ronald_Reagan_High_School_(San_Antonio,_Texas)|Reagan High School]]
[[Theodore_Roosevelt_High_School_(San_Antonio)|Roosevelt High School]]
[[San Antonio Scorpions FC]] (2012) }} '''Heroes Stadium''' is an 11,000-seat, open style [[American Football|football]] [[stadium]] serving the public school district [[North East Independent School District |North East ISD]] in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], USA. It opened in 2009, built on the {{convert|58|acre|m2|adj=on}} site of the abandoned Longhorn Quarry, and has 2,525 paved parking spaces.{{cite web|url=http://www.neisd.net/constr/bonds/projects/heroes_stadium/2007/site.htm|title=2007 Bond Project: Heroes Stadium|publisher=NEISD}} $27.5 million of funding was provided by a 2007 school district bond.{{cite web|url=http://www.neisd.net/constr/bonds/projects/heroes_stadium/2007/index.html|title=2007 Bond Project|publisher=NEISD}} A video board system measuring {{convert|15|by|25|ft|m|abbr=on}} was installed in 2010. Along with [[Comalander Stadium]], Heroes is the home venue for the football, track and field, soccer, and band events for the high schools in the [[North East Independent School District]], and also plays host to various athletic events for the district's middle and elementary schools. The stadium received national exposure on August 27, 2010, when it held a game between local [[James Madison High School (San Antonio, Texas)|Madison Mavericks]] and [http://www.scuc.txed.net/ByronSteele.cfm Steele Knights] of [[Cibolo, Texas|Cibolo]]. The game was televised by [[ESPN]], as part of its High School Rise Kickoff Event.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/recruiting/football/news/story?id=5500773|title=Steele Knights vs. Madison Mavericks|publisher=ESPN}} The venue hosted the [[San Antonio Scorpions FC|San Antonio Scorpions]] in their inaugural [[2012 San Antonio Scorpions FC season|2012]] [[North American Soccer League (2011)|NASL]] [[2012 North American Soccer League season|season]].{{cite web|title=NASL chief gives OK to Heroes
Stadium|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/sports/article/NASL-chief-gives-OK-to-Heroes-Stadium-1354089.php|publisher=San Antonio Express-News}} The team played at the site to an average attendance of 9,176, including a couple of sellout crowds,{{cite web|last=dohertysoocer|title=2012 NASL Attendance|url=http://dohertysoccer.com/2012-lower-division-attendance/2012-nasl-attendance/|publisher=dohertysoocer}} while their stadium, [[Toyota Field]], was being completed. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.texasbob.com/stadium/stadium.php?id=1276 Texas Bob Stadium Reference Page] {{NASL Stadiums}} [[Category:North American Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:North East Independent School District]] [[Category:Sports venues in San Antonio]] [[Category:High school football venues in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Texas]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Texas]] {{NEISD}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Koning Willem II Stadion | nickname = | fullname = Koning Willem II Stadion | former names = Willem II Stadion (1995–2009)
Koning Willem II Stadion (2009–present) | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[Image:Willem II stadion.jpg|250px]] | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | address = | location = Goirleseweg 34,
5026 PC [[Tilburg]]
[[Netherlands]] | coordinates = | type = | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 14,700 | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = [[Willem II Tilburg]] | website = }} '''Koning Willem II Stadion''' ({{IPA-nl|ˌkoːnɪŋ ˌʋɪləm ˈtʋeː ˌstaːdijɔn}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Tilburg]], [[Netherlands]], and the home ground of [[Willem II Tilburg]]. It is currently used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches. The stadium is able to hold 14,700 people, was built in 1995 and renovated in 2000 to add business lodges, a restaurant, conference rooms, business club and a supporters bar to the main building. The new stadium is built on the same spot as the old stadium, the [[Gemeentelijk Sportpark Tilburg]], which had a smaller capacity and fewer facilities. This stadium was demolished in 1992. The current stadium opened in 1995.{{cite web|title=Koning Willem II Stadion|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=18 August 2017|url=https://int.soccerway.com/venues/netherlands/willem-ii-stadion/v274/}} The original name was ''Willem II Stadion'', but in 2009 the stadium was renamed ''Koning'' ("King") ''Willem II Stadion'', honoring [[William II of the Netherlands]]. {{coord|51|32|34|N|5|04|01|E|display=title|region:NL_type:landmark_source:nlwiki}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Football venues in the Netherlands}} [[Category:Football venues in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Willem II Tilburg]] [[Category:Sports venues in North Brabant]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1995]] [[Category:UEFA Women's Euro 2017 venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tilburg]] [[Category:Sport in Tilburg]] {{Netherlands-sports-venue-stub}}

[[File:Théodore Géricault - Riderless Racers at Rome - Walters 37189.jpg|right|upright=1.2|thumb|''Riderless Racers at Rome'' by [[Théodore Géricault]]. From the mid-15th century until 1882, spring carnival in Rome closed with a horse race.]]
'''List of different forms of racing'''.
== Running == {{Main|Running}} [[File:100m women Golden League 2007 in Zurich.jpg|thumb|The finish of a women's 100 m race]] Running is defined in [[sport]]ing terms as a [[gait]] in which at some point all feet are off the ground at the same time. This is in contrast to [[walking]], where one foot is always in contact with the ground. The term running can refer to any of a variety of speeds ranging from [[jogging]] to [[Sprint (running)|sprinting]]. Competitive running grew out of religious festivals in various areas. The [[Ancient_Olympic_Games#Origins|origins of the Olympics]] are shrouded in myth, though the first recorded game took place in 776 BCE.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cgkzWTugSj0C&pg=PA201&dq=first+recorded+victor+of+the+stade-race+in+776&hl=en&ei=1MYlTNDBDJCNOO3WrPAC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=first%20recorded%20victor%20of%20the%20stade-race%20in%20776&f=false |title=The Ancient Olympics - Google Books |publisher=books.google.com |accessdate=2010-06-26 }}</ref> In [[Gaelic Ireland]] the [[Tailteann Games (ancient)|Tailteann Games]], which featured footraces, are attested from the 6th century CE; medieval chroniclers gave founding dates as early as 1829 BCE. * [[Running]] ** [[Adventure running]] ** [[Cross country running]] ** [[Fell running]] ** [[Marathon]] ** [[Road running]] ** [[Track running]] in [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] ** [[Trail running]] ** [[Tower running]]
==Orienteering== {{Main|Orienteering}} [[Image:Wilimy.jpg|thumb|right|Mountain bike orienteering]] Orienteering sports combine [[navigation]] with a specific method of travel.
*[[Foot orienteering]], navigation using a [[Orienteering map|map]] and [[compass]] while running across unfamiliar terrain along a [[course (orienteering)|course]] with [[Control point (orienteering)|control points]]. *[[Mountain bike orienteering]] *[[Ski-orienteering|Ski orienteering]] *[[Trail orienteering]] *[[Amateur radio direction finding|Radio orienteering]], combines [[radio direction finding]] with orienteering skills. Other variations are [[Fox Oring]] and [[Radio Orienteering in a Compact Area]]. *[[Canoe orienteering]] *[[Mounted orienteering]] *[[Rogaining]], cross-country navigation between checkpoints in free order within a time frame. * SportLabyrinth - micro orienteering *[[Mountain marathon]], mountain navigation while running off road over upland country. *[[Car orienteering]]
==Walking== * [[Racewalking]], a long-distance athletic event where one foot must be in contact with the ground at all times.
==Swimming== [[File:Depart4x100.jpg|thumb|Start of the 4x100 meters relay in the Watercube, [[Swimming at the 2008 Summer Olympics|Beijing]], August 11, 2008]] * [[swimming (sport)|Swimming]] * [[Paralympic swimming]]
==Cycling == [[Bicycle racing]]: * [[Track cycling]], such as a [[Points race]] * [[Road bicycle racing]], such as the [[Tour de France]] * [[Mountain biking]], where a [[bicycle]] is ridden off-road ** [[Mountain bike orienteering]], [[navigation]] along off-road trails and tracks * [[BMX]] (Bicycle Motocross)
== Winter racing == * [[Skiing]] ** [[Alpine skiing]] such as [[Slalom skiing]], [[Downhill skiing]], [[Giant slalom skiing]], [[Super Giant Slalom skiing]] and [[Speed skiing]] ** [[Cross-country skiing]] *** [[Ski-orienteering]], that combines [[cross-country skiing]] and [[orienteering]] *** [[Biathlon]], that combines [[cross-country skiing]] and [[rifle|rifle shooting]] * [[Snowboarding]] * [[Ice skating|Skating]] ** [[Speed skating]] * [[Sledding]] ** [[Bobsleigh]] ** [[Kicksled]] ** [[Luge]] ** [[Skeleton (sport)|Skeleton]]
== Animal racing == [[Image:OstrichCartJacksonville1.jpg|thumb|[[Ostrich#Racing|Ostrich racing]]]] [[Animal racing]]: * Bull racing (or Buffalo racing) ** [[Buffalo racing in Kerala]] ** [[Karapan sapi|Bull racing in Madura]] * [[Camel racing]] * [[Greyhound racing]] * [[Sled dog racing]], such as the [[Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race]] * [[Horse racing]], see also [[United Kingdom horse-racing]] and [[Equestrianism]] ** [[Chariot racing]] ** [[Flat racing]] ** [[Thoroughbred horse race]]s, such as [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing]] or a [[Derby (horse race)|Derby]]. ** [[Trotting]] ** [[steeplechase (horse racing)|Steeplechase]] * [[Kambala]] * [[Karapan sapi]] * Lobster Racing * [[Pigeon racing]] * [[Pig racing]] * Ostrich racing * [[Snail racing]] * [[Skijoring]] * [[Turtle Racing]] * Zebra Racing

Racing scene ]] * [[All-terrain vehicle]] * [[Auto racing]] (also known as ''automobile racing'' or ''autosport'') ** [[Board track racing]] ** [[Drag racing]] ** [[Dirt track racing]] ** [[Ice racing]] ** [[Open wheel racing]] *** [[Formula racing]] *** [[Midget car racing]] *** [[Sprint car racing]] ** [[Offroad racing]] ** [[Pickup truck racing]] ** [[Production car racing]] ** [[Rally racing]] ** [[Rallycross]] ** [[Road racing]] ** [[Sports car racing]] ** [[Stock car racing]] ** [[Touring car racing]] ** [[Truck racing]] * [[Kart racing]] * [[Lawnmower racing]] * [[Motorcycle racing]] ** [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing]] ** [[Pocketbike racing]] ** [[Production Bike Racing]] ** [[Superbike racing]] ** [[Track racing]] *** Flat Track *** [[Motorcycle speedway|Speedway]] *** [[Grasstrack]] (aka Long Track) ** [[Motocross]] *** [[Supercross]] *** Beachcross ** [[Supermoto]] (aka Supermotard) * [[Snowmobile]] racing * [[Motorboat]] racing ** [[Hydroplane racing]] ** [[Jet sprint boat racing]] ** [[Offshore powerboat racing]] * Model racing ** [[Radio-controlled model]] racing ** [[Slot car racing]]
== Boat racing == {{Main|Boat racing}} * [[Canoe racing]] ** [[Canoe orienteering]] * [[Drag boat racing]] * [[Dragon boat race|Dragon boat racing]] * [[Hydroplane racing]] * [[Jet sprint boat racing]] * [[Offshore powerboat racing]] * [[Outrigger Canoe racing]] * [[Sport rowing|Rowing]] * [[Sailing (sport)|Sailing]] * [[Yacht racing]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 813885978 by [[Special:Contributions/192.35.35.36|192.35.35.36]] ([[User talk:192.35.35.36|talk]]): the metric mile discussed here is definitely not the same as a statue mile.
revision.text:
{{for|the 10 kilometer mile|Scandinavian mile}} <!-- {{Unit of length |m=1600 |accuracy=4}} --> <!--number of significant figures--> A '''metric mile''' is a distance which approximates one statute [[mile]] (1609.344 m) at a round figure of [[metre]]s (the [[SI]] or metric unit of length). The term is most commonly used in [[track running]] and [[swimming (sport)|swimming]].
In track running, the [[1500 metres|1500 m race]] became the standard [[middle distance track event|middle distance race]] in Europe in the late 19th century,<ref name=nelsonpluquercetania>{{cite book | last = [[Cordner Nelson|Nelson]] | first = [[Cordner Nelson|Cordner]] |author2=Quercetani, Roberto | title = The Milers | url = | year= 1985 | isbn = 0-911521-15-1 | page=14 }}</ref> and has been the standard distance in the Olympic Games since 1896. The distance of the race is sometimes referred to as a metric mile.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9052542/middle-distance-running|title=Middle-distance running|accessdate=2008-01-13}}</ref>
Prior to [[metrication]], many tracks in the United States and the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] were constructed to the specifications of one quarter of a mile, 440 yards (402.336 m). Thus when the [[mile run|mile]] was run, the race was a four lap race. The Commonwealth officially converted to metric in the mid-1960s. The [[Metrication in the United States#Sports|United States adopted metric rules]] in the mid to late 1970s, though some tracks are still constructed to be a quarter of a mile in length requiring calibrated painted lines to run metric races.
Even in countries [[United States customary units|like the U.S]]. which do not embrace the metric system, most running tracks now have a lap distance of [[400 metres]] in the innermost lane. The final leg of a [[distance medley relay]] uses a four lap 1600 m leg; The standard middle distance in many [[United States]] [[National Federation of State High School Associations|high school competitions]] is 1600 m and this distance is sometimes referred to as a metric mile as well.
In swimming, the 1500 m (or 1650 yards) race is commonly referred to as "the swimmer's mile", and is often the longest distance swum by competitors in a pool. The standard distance triathlon also employs the swimmer's mile, except in open water instead of a pool.
==See also== * [[Metric foot]] * [[Metrication]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Units of length]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) terminology]] [[Category:Middle-distance running|Track running]] [[Category:Decimalisation]]

{{Infobox medical intervention | name = Microfracture surgery | synonym = | image = File:Gray348.png|thumb| | caption = Left knee-joint from behind, showing interior ligaments. ([[Lateral meniscus]] and [[medial meniscus]] are cartilage.)]] | alt = | pronounce = | specialty = orthopedic | synonyms = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9unlinked = | CPT = | MeshID = | LOINC = | other_codes = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicine = }} '''Microfracture surgery''' is an [[articular cartilage repair]] [[surgery|surgical technique]] that works by creating tiny [[Bone fracture|fractures]] in the underlying [[bone]]. This causes new cartilage to develop from a so-called super-clot.
The surgery is quick (typically lasting between 30–90 minutes), minimally invasive, and can have a significantly shorter recovery time than an [[arthroplasty]] ([[knee replacement]]).
Chronic articular cartilage defects do not heal spontaneously.<ref>Hunter W (1743) "On the structure and diseases of articulating cartilages." Trans R Soc Lond 42B:514-21</ref> However, acute traumatic osteochondral lesions or surgically created lesions extending into subchondral bone, e.g. by [[Kenneth Pridie|Pridie]] drilling,<ref>Pridie K (1959) ''A method of resurfacing osteoarthritic knee joints.'' J Bone Joint Surg Br 41-B(3):618-619</ref> spongialization<ref>Ficat RP, Ficat C, Gedeon P, Toussaint JB (1979) ''Spongialization: a new treatment for diseased patellae.'' Clin Orthop Relat Res (144):74-83</ref> abrasion<ref>Johnson LL (1986) ''Arthroscopic abrasion arthroplasty historical and pathologic perspective: present status.'' Arthroscopy 2(1):54-69</ref> or microfracture causing the release of multipotent mesenchymal stem cells from the bone marrow, may heal with repair tissue consisting of fibrous tissue, fibrocartilage or hyaline-like cartilage.<ref>Key JA (1931) ''Experimental arthritis: The changes in joints produced by creating defects in the articular cartilage.'' J Bone Joint Surg Am 13(4):725-739</ref> The quality of the repair tissue after these "bone marrow stimulating techniques" depends on various factors including the species and age of the individual, the size and localization of the articular cartilage defect, the surgical technique, e.g., how the subchondral bone plate is treated, and the postoperative rehabilitation protocol.<ref>Alford JW, Cole BJ (2005) ''Cartilage restoration, part 2: techniques, outcomes, and future directions.'' Am J Sports Med 33(3):443-460</ref>
==History== The surgery was developed in the late 1980s and early 1990s by Dr. [[Richard Steadman]] of the Steadman-Hawkins [[clinic]] in [[Vail, Colorado]]. Steadman slowly refined the procedure through research (including tests on [[horse]]s).<ref>[http://www.knee1.com/hero/hero.cfm/19/1 Dr. Richard Steadman: Pioneer in Cartilage Regeneration], interview by Neal Patel, Knee1.com, July 31, 2000</ref> The surgery was soon called "controversial" by many [[sportswriting|sportswriters]], due to a lack of studies on the long-term effects and the fact that an unsuccessful surgery could end an athlete's career.<ref>[http://static.espn.go.com/nfl/trainingcamp03/columns/bills/observations/1590409.html "Bills looking for more balance on offense"], Len Pasquarelli, [[ESPN.com]], August 5, 2003</ref> Dr. Steadman has also adapted the surgery into a treatment to help reattach torn ligaments (a technique he calls the "healing response")
==Procedure== The surgery is performed by [[arthroscopy]], after the joint is cleaned of calcified cartilage. Through use of an [[wikt:awl|awl]], the surgeon creates tiny fractures in the subchondral bone plate.<ref name="thegoodpoint.com">[http://thegoodpoint.com/2010/07/microfracture-knee-surgery-nba/ "Microfracture knee surgery and its impact on the NBA"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723004848/http://thegoodpoint.com/2010/07/microfracture-knee-surgery-nba/ |date=2012-07-23 }}, Austin Kent, ''The Good Point'' July 26, 2010</ref> [[Blood]] and [[bone marrow]] (which contains [[stem cell]]s) seep out of the fractures, creating a [[blood clot]] that releases cartilage-building [[cell (biology)|cell]]s. The microfractures are treated as an injury by the body, which is why the surgery results in new, replacement cartilage.<ref name="nytimes">[http://www.shsmf.org/pdf/fallwinter0506.pdf "Older Knees Now Have New Option"], Vicky Lowry, ''[[New York Times]]'', April 5, 2005 (reprinted with permission in Steadman-Hawkins Research Foundation newsletter, Vol 11 (Fall-Winter) 2005-06)</ref> The procedure is less effective in treating older patients, overweight patients, or a cartilage lesion larger than 2.5 cm.<ref name="nytimes" /> Further on, chances are high that after only 1 or 2 years of the surgery symptoms start to return as the fibrocartilage wears away, forcing the patient to reengage in articular cartilage repair.
The effectiveness of cartilage growth after microfracture surgery is thought to be dependent on the patient's bone marrow stem cell population and some think increasing the number of stem cells increases the chances of success. A couple of physicians are promoting an alternative treatment implanting [[autologous]] mesenchymal stem cells directly into the cartilage defect, without having to penetrate the subchondral bone.<ref>Centeno CJ, Busse D, Kisiday J, Keohan C, Freeman M, Karli D Increased knee cartilage volume in degenerative joint disease using percutaneously implanted, autologous mesenchymal stem cells. Pain Physician. 2008 May-Jun;11(3):343-53.</ref><ref>Christopher Centeno, Dan Busse, John Kisiday, Cristin Keohan, Michael Freeman Increased knee cartilage volume in degenerative joint disease using percutaneously implanted, autologous mesenchymal stem cells, platelet lysate and dexamethasone http://www.amjcaserep.com/index.php?/archives/article/855038</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chondral Injury & Microfracture|url=http://tony-gibbon.co.uk/treatment/knee-treatment/injuries-problems/chondral-injury-microfracture|publisher=North Yorkshire Orthopaedic Specialists|accessdate=18 February 2013}}</ref>
==Microfracture Reports== Studies have shown that microfracture techniques do not fill in the chondral defect fully, forming [[fibrocartilage]] rather than [[hyaline cartilage]]. Fibrocartilage is not as mechanically sound as hyaline cartilage; it is much denser and unable to withstand the demands of everyday activities as well as the original cartilage and is thus at higher risk of breaking down.<ref name="cartilagehealth.com">"Articular cartilage repair of the knee" by Karen Hambly. www.cartilagehealth.com/acr.html</ref> The blood clot is very delicate after surgery and needs to be protected. In terms of time, the clot takes about 8 to 15 weeks for conversion to fibrous tissue and is usually fibrocartilage by about four months post surgery, holding implications for the rehabilitation.<ref name="cartilagehealth.com"/>
'''[[Autologous Chondrocyte Implantation|Chondrocyte Implantation]] procedures''' (CCI), a cell based [[articular cartilage repair]] procedure that aims to provide complete hyaline repair tissues for articular cartilage repair, have been posed by some as an alternative to microfracture surgery. In February 2008, Saris ''et. al'' published a large-scale study claiming that CCI results in better structural repair for symptomatic cartilage defects of the knee than microfracture surgery. According to the study, one year after treatment, the tissue regenerate associated with CCI is of better quality than that of microfracture surgery.<ref>Characterized Chondrocyte Implantation Results in Better Structural Repair When Treating Symptomatic Cartilage Defects of the Knee in a Randomized Controlled Trial Versus microfracture, The American Journal of Sports Medicine volume 36 number 2, pp 235-246. February 2008</ref>
==Use in professional sports== There have been many notable professional athletes who have undergone the procedure. Partially because of the high level of stress placed on the knees by these athletes, the surgery is not a [[Panacea (medicine)|panacea]] and results have been mixed. Many players' careers effectively end despite the surgery. However, some players such as [[Jason Kidd]], [[Steve Yzerman]], [[John Stockton]], [[Kenyon Martin]] and [[Zach Randolph]]<ref>http://www.nba.com/features/stoudemire_060713.html</ref> have been able to return at or near their pre-surgery form while players [[Ron Harper]], [[Brian Grant]], [[Chris Webber]], [[Allan Houston]], [[Penny Hardaway]], and the late [[Derek Smith (basketball)|Derek Smith]] never regained their old form.<ref name="thegoodpoint.com"/> Others such as [[Jamal Mashburn]] and [[Terrell Brandon]] never recovered and retired. Portland Trail Blazers rookie [[Greg Oden]] underwent the procedure on his right knee in early September 2007 and missed the entire 2007-2008 NBA season. At only 19 at the time of the surgery, doctors were confident that he would return to at or near full strength by the 2008-2009 season; he had a second microfracture surgery, this time on his left knee, in November 2010. Subsequently, Oden did not play in the NBA for over four years, missing the entirety of the 2011-2012 and 2012-2013 NBA seasons.<ref>[http://www.nba.com/blazers/news/Oden_Undergoes_Microfracture_S-236705-1218.html] "Greg Oden undergoes microfracture surgery"</ref> The former San Antonio Spurs and Houston Rockets player, [[Tracy McGrady]] also underwent microfracture surgery; doctors were confident that the 2 time scoring champion will return to full strength. As of 2012 he has not had the same speed and jumping ability as he formerly did. He retired in 2013, never regaining his previous form after the surgery.
In October 2005, young star [[Amar'e Stoudemire]] of the [[NBA]]'s [[Phoenix Suns]] underwent one of the highest-profile microfracture surgeries to date. He returned to the court in March 2006 and initially appeared to have made a full recovery, but subsequently started feeling stiffness in both knees (his right knee had been overcompensating for the injured left knee). He and the team doctor decided he needed more time to rehab and he did not return until the [[2006-2007 NBA season]].<ref>[http://www.azcentral.com/sports/suns/articles/0330amare0330.html "Amaré back in Valley"], Paul Coro, ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'', March 30, 2006</ref> During the 2006-2007 season, Stoudemire returned to form, averaging 20.4 points and 9.6 rebounds per game while playing in all 82 regular-season games and the [[2007 NBA All-Star Game]]. His recent success has brought positive publicity to the procedure, further distancing it from a previous reputation as a possible "career death sentence" in the sports world, though he was one of the youngest of the aforementioned players to undergo the surgery.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/dailydime?page=dailydime-070317-18&lpos=spotlight&lid=tab3pos2.html "The Daily Dime 3.17.07: 10 Drops of NBA Knowledge. (Section 3, Western Conference)"], Marc Stein, ''[[ESPN.com]]'', March 17, 2007</ref>
In June 2010, Grady Sizemore of the Cleveland Indians underwent microfracture surgery after injuring his left knee while diving back to first base earlier in the season. Sizemore was re-activated as the Indians center fielder in April 2011, ending an 11-month stretch of being disabled due to his injury. In his first game back on April 17, 2011 Sizemore showed no signs of slowing down as he had 2 hits in 4 AB which included a double and Home Run. Currently, Sizemore is the only player in MLB history to come back from knee microfracture surgery and play centerfield.<ref>[https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/news;_ylt=AqFuAru29XU4ld.0iuQMrYARvLYF?slug=jp-passan_grady_sizemore_indians_knee_royals_041811] "Sizemore’s running and Indians are winning"</ref>
Vontaze Burfict, a linebacker for the Cincinnati Bengals, is one of the few notable NFL players to have the surgery. <ref>http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000463388/article/bengals-vontaze-burfict-had-microfracture-surgery</ref>
==Recovery== One study has shown a success rate of 75 to 80 percent among patients 45 years of age or younger.<ref name="journal">[http://www.arthroscopyjournal.org/article/PIIS0749806303001245/abstract "Outcomes of microfracture for traumatic chondral defects of the knee: Average 11-year follow-up"], Steadman et al., ''Arthroscopy: The Journal of Arthroscopic and Related Surgery'', Vol 19, No 5 (May–June), 2003: pp 477–484</ref><ref name="mednews">[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=38404 Orthopaedic Surgeon Performs Innovative Microfracture Procedure On Arthritic Knees Avoiding Knee Replacement Surgery], Medical News Today, February 26, 2006</ref> It is an outpatient procedure and causes only small discomfort. The harder part is the restrictions that are placed on the patient during the post-operative recovery period. This can be a major challenge for many patients. For optimal re-growth of joint surface, the patients need to be very patient and also extremely cooperative. They usually need to be on crutches for four to six weeks (sometimes longer). Sometimes a brace is needed. This all depends on the size and/or location of the joint surface defect that is being repaired or regenerated. The patients are encouraged to spend approximately 6–8 hours a day on a CPM ([[Continuous Passive Motion]]) machine that helps with optimal re-growth of joint surface. The procedure can be painless for some patients that the patients avoid these critically important steps and expose the knee to physical activity before the joint fully heals. However, with other patients the procedure can be very painful for weeks even months. Pain medication may be required to manage pain levels in those patients.
Steadman cites the significance of a patient's natural joint alignment in addition to disciplined rehabilitation in recovery from the procedure.<ref name="thegoodpoint.com"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/007255.htm MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Podgorica City Stadium | image =Downtown, Podgorica, Montenegro - panoramio (1).jpg | caption = | nickname = Stadion Pod Goricom | location = Vaka Đurovića street, [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1945 | renovated = 2004–2006 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[City of Podgorica]] | operator = [[Football Association of Montenegro]], [[Montenegrin Cup]] Final, [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|FK Budućnost]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | floodlights = 1,900 lux <ref name="fscg.me">{{cite web|url=http://fscg.me/selekcije-2/4844-qsokoliq-trenirali-pod-novim-reflektorima|title=Fudbalski savez Crne Gore|website=fscg.me}}</ref> | tenants = [[Montenegro national football team]], [[Montenegro Cup]] Final, [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|FK Budućnost]] | seating_capacity = 15,230<ref>https://www.uefa.com/MultimediaFiles/Download/FirstDiv/uefaorg/Publications/01/67/03/93/1670393_DOWNLOAD.pdf UEFA Multimedia PDF file</ref> | record_attendance = 20,000 ([[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]] - [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]], 1975) | dimensions = 105 x 70 metres }}
'''Podgorica City Stadium''' ([[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]]: ''Stadion pod Goricom'') is an all-seater [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Podgorica]], [[Montenegro]]. Mostly used for [[association football|football matches]], it has a [[seating capacity]] of 15,230. The planned capacity of stadium, after the next reconstruction of the east stand, is over 18,000. The stadium is the home ground of [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegrin national football team]] and [[FK Budućnost Podgorica]] ([[Montenegrin First League]]).
==History== [[Image:Stadion pod Goricom.jpg|thumb|right|West stand in September 2005|270px]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:PodgoricaFootballStadium.png|thumb|left|Podgorica City Stadium|300px]] --> Podgorica City Stadium was built in 1945, following [[World War II]]. Before the war, [[FK Budućnost Podgorica]] and other clubs from Podgorica played their matches in a field near that location.
The stadium's original capacity was around 5,000 spectators. The stadium burned down completely in 1952, but was later rebuilt, with a new capacity of about 17,000 seats. The new stadium has four stands—west, east, south and north.
In 1989, floodlights were installed in the City Stadium in Podgorica (then known as Titograd). During the 1980s, the main stand (west) was reconstructed. The new stand has a seating capacity of 6,000 and a modern roof.
After the breakup of [[SFR Yugoslavia]], the stadium underwent additional construction work. The east stand was torn down, and a new north stand was built. Capacity was reduced to 12,000.
The latest construction work took place between 2004 and 2006. The south and north stand were renovated, with two tiers (lower tier and upper tier). On both sides, the capacity of the lower tier is 1,000 seats, and the capacity of upper tier is 2,500. Both stands are all-seater with roofs. During the last reconstruction, a new east stand was built.
The stadium's current capacity is 15,230, but for international games there are about 13,000 free-seats, because most seats on the south stand are reserved for guest supporters. The north stand is the home of [[FK Budućnost Podgorica]] fans, the popular ''Varvari'' (''Barbarians''). Varvari often account for a large percentage of the attendance at games featuring FK Budućnost. They are the largest [[ultras]] group in Montenegro.
===Current capacity===
Since 2006, Podgorica City Stadium has had four stands. From 1992 to 2006, there was three stands (after the old east stand was torn down). Below is current capacity of all stands with technical details.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Stand !Built !Renovated !Levels !Capacity !Sectors !Entrances |- |style="text-align:left;"|'''West'''||1945||1952-1953, 1984-1985, 2004||1||'''6,200'''||8 (VIP + media)||7 |- |style="text-align:left;"|'''East'''||1952-53||2006||1||'''2,030'''||8||2 |- |style="text-align:left;"|'''North'''||1952-53||1992-1993, 2004-2005||2||'''3,500'''||8||5 |- |style="text-align:left;"|'''South'''||1952-53||2004-2005||2||'''3,500'''||8||5 |- |colspan="4"|'''Overall'''||'''15,230'''||'''32'''||'''19''' |}
===Next works=== Works on rebuilding the East Stand have been announced to start in 2017, and are planned to increase the stadium capacity to over 20,000.
==Pitch and floodlights== [[Image:Montenegrinfans1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Montenegro national football team]] game|300px]] The [[Association football pitch|pitch]] measures 105 by 70 meters. The stadium is well-known for close distance between pitch and stands. The Pitch was totally renovated in 2014 and today is among the best football pitches in the Balkans.
Floodlights were installed 1989 for the first nighttime match, [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[FK Rad|Rad]] (First League, 28 May 1989). Twenty years later, new 1900 lux floodlights were installed.<ref name="fscg.me"/>
==Users== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Stadium Pod Goricom.jpg||300px|right|thumb|Podgorica City Stadium]] --> During its history, the Podgorica City Stadium was used by a few clubs and [[Football Association of Montenegro]].
It is the host stadium for the [[Montenegro national football team]].
Before the [[Montenegrin independence referendum, 2006|independence of Montenegro]], the Podgorica City Stadium hosted the final of the [[Montenegrin Republic Cup (1947-2006)|Republic Cup of Montenegro]]. Following this tradition, Podgorica City Stadium is now the host venue of every [[Montenegrin Cup]] final.
Clubs which played their host matches at the Podgorica City Stadium are:
*1945–present: [[FK Budućnost Podgorica]] *1953-1997: [[FK Mladost Podgorica]]
==Records== *'''First match:''' [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[FK Sutjeska Nikšić|Sutjeska]], friendly game, 3 May 1945 *'''First official match:''' [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[FK Arsenal Tivat|Arsenal Tivat]], [[Montenegrin clubs in Yugoslav football competitions (1946–2006)#Montenegrin Republic League|Montenegrin Republic League]], 20 April 1946 *'''First match in the First League:''' [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[GNK Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo Zagreb]], [[Yugoslav First League]], 25 August 1946 *'''First match under the floodlights:''' [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[FK Rad|Rad]], [[Yugoslav First League]], 28 May 1989 *'''First international match:''' [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[KF Tirana|Tirana]], friendly game, 7 January 1946 *'''First official international match:''' [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]]-[[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]], [[UEFA Euro 1972 qualifying|Euro 1972 qualifiers]], 27 October 1971 *'''First match of Montenegrin national team:''' [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]]-[[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], friendly game, 24 March 2007 *'''Highest attendance:''' 20,000-[[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]], [[Yugoslav First League]], 27 August 1975
==Highest attendances and notable matches== [[Image:Varvari-radza.jpg|thumb|right|[[FK Budućnost Podgorica|FK Budućnost]] fans at ''pod Goricom''|300px]] Notable matches played at the stadium include:
===Before 2006=== *[[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]]-[[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]], [[UEFA Euro 1972 qualifying|Euro 1972 qualifiers]], 27 October 1971 - att: 15,000 *[[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]], [[Yugoslav First League]], 27 August 1975 - att: 20,000 *[[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]]-[[Wales national football team|Wales]], [[UEFA Euro 1984 qualifying|Euro 1984 qualifiers]], 15 December 1982 - att: 17,000 *[[FK Budućnost Podgorica|Budućnost]]-[[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]], [[Intertoto Cup]], 9 July 2005 - att: 10,000
===After 2006=== *[[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]]-[[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], 24 March 2007 - att: 12,000 *[[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]]-[[Italy national football team|Italy]], [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup 2010 qualifiers]], 28 March 2009 - att: 11,500 *[[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]]-[[England national football team|England]], [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying|Euro 2012 qualifiers]], 7 October 2011 - att: 11,500 *[[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]]-[[England national football team|England]], [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup 2014 qualifiers]], 26 March 2013 - att: 13,000
==Controversies and accidents== During the history, stadium in Podgorica was a place of numerous accidental situations, especially on FK Budućnost matches. Crowd violence escalated in the early 1970s, and after that—in the new century.
===FK Budućnost games=== In 2004, at the [[2004–05 First League of Serbia and Montenegro|First League]] Budućnost-Partizan Belgrade match, blocks, construction materials and similar objects were thrown from the north stand to the pitch and the match was halted for 15 minutes. A year later, the Budućnost-Crvena Zvezda Belgrade match was suspended for two hours after home supporters (''Varvari'') threw tear gas on the pitch and, after that, attacked visitors' ultras.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.72.html:164060-Suzavac-pod-Goricom|title=Suzavac pod Goricom!|website=www.novosti.rs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sansasport.com/fudbal/domaci-fudbal/4100-na-danasnji-dan|title=Na današnji dan prije 11 godina: Suzavac, stampedo i onda lagan trijumf Zvezde (FOTO+VIDEO) - Šansa sport|publisher=}}</ref> In Spring 2006, there was crowd violence at the local rivals match Budućnost-Zeta.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mondo.rs/a18003/Sport/Fudbal/Buducnost-kaznjena-oduzimanjem-bodova.html|title=Budućnost kažnjena oduzimanjem bodova|publisher=}}</ref> In [[Montenegrin First League]], numerous matches of FK Budućnost were suspended due to crowd violence or crowd-invasion to the pitch.
===Montenegro games=== [[Image:MontenegrinFans2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Montenegro national football team]] game in Podgorica|300px]] With the full crowd at every important match, and the architecture of the stands which are only four meters away from the pitch-lines, games of Montenegrin national team are playing in the highly-electric atmosphere. During the past years, Montenegrin FA is sanctioned by UEFA and FIFA in numerous occasions.
In 2011, after the Montenegro-England match, Montenegrin ultras intruded upon the pitch. During the game, missiles and flares were hurled at goalkeeper [[Joe Hart]] while he was in front of ''Ultra Montenegro'' group.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9957947/Montenegro-face-Fifa-sanctions-following-crowd-disorder-during-the-1-1-draw-with-England-in-Podgorica.html|title=Montenegro face Fifa sanctions following crowd disorder during the 1-1 draw with England in Podgorica|first=Jeremy|last=Wilson|date=27 March 2013|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> The same thing occurred a year later in the match between Montenegro and Poland.
On 27 March 2015, [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]] had a home match against [[Russia national football team|Russia]]. The match was abandoned after 67 minutes due to crowd violence (during the match, the Russian goalkeeper was hit by [[Dmitri Kombarov]], who was hit by an object). The original score was 0-0 and Russia missed a penalty moment before the match was abandoned. Russian goalkeeper [[Igor Akinfeev]] was hit by a flare, causing a second 33-minute delay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/montenegro-arrests-fans-for-football-match-bowl|title=Montenegro Arrests Fans for Football Violence :: Balkan Insight|website=www.balkaninsight.com}}</ref> After that game, barriers were constructed in the upper portions of the stadium to prevent similar incidents in the future.

{{Infobox sportsperson | name = Rosie Ruiz | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | headercolor = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = USA | ethnicity = | citizenship = USA | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1953}} | birth_place = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | agent = | height = | weight = | spouse = | life_partner = | other_interests = | website = | module = | country = Cuba | sport = [[track and field]] | position = | rank = 8th | event = Boston Marathon | collegeteam = | universityteam = | league = | league_type = | club = | team = | turnedpro = | partner = | former_partner = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | module2 = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | highestranking = | pb = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = | updated = }} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{spanish name|Ruiz|Vivas}} '''Rosie Ruiz''' (born 1953) is a [[Cuban American]] runner who was declared the winner in the female category for the 84th [[Boston Marathon]] in 1980, only to have her title stripped eight days after the race when it was discovered that she had not run the entire course. She is believed to have jumped onto the course about a half-mile before the finish.
== Background == Ruiz was born '''Rosa Ruiz Vivas''' in [[Havana]], Cuba, and moved to [[Memphis, Florida]] with her family in 1962.<ref name=SI1>[https://www.si.com/vault/1980/05/05/824629/scorecard Scorecard]. [[Sports Illustrated]], May 5, 1980.</ref> She moved to [[New York City]] in the early 1970s, eventually finding work with Metal Traders, a commodities firm. In 1979, she qualified for the [[New York City Marathon]] and was credited with a time of 2:56:29, the 11th woman overall—enough to qualify her for the Boston Marathon.<ref name=EagleTribune>Burt, Bill. [http://www.eagletribune.com/sports/rosie-s-run-how-rosie-ruiz-became-one-of-the/article_0acd2008-f49f-5403-be9e-31138b0e36c4.html Rosie's Run]. ''[[The Eagle-Tribune]]'', April 16, 2000.</ref>
== Boston Marathon == On April 21, 1980, Ruiz appeared to win the Boston Marathon's female category with a time of 2:31:56. Her time would have been the fastest female time in Boston Marathon history as well as the third-fastest female time ever recorded in any marathon.<ref name=MassMoments>[http://www.massmoments.org/moment.cfm?mid=120 Mass Moments: Rosie Ruiz Steals Boston Marathon]. Massachusetts Foundation for the Humanities, April 21, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/archive/permalink/rosie_ruiz_wins_the_boston_marathon Rosie Ruiz wins the Boston Marathon] at [[Museum of Hoaxes]]</ref><ref name=SI2>Moore, Kenny. [https://www.si.com/vault/1980/04/28/824607/mastery-and-mystery-bill-rodgers-above-tied-the-record-with-a-third-straight-boston-marathon-victory-but-who-was-first-to-finish-the-full-distance-among-the-women-was-open-to-question Mastery and Mystery]. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', April 28, 1980.</ref> However, suspicions mounted about Ruiz almost from the beginning. Men's winner [[Bill Rodgers (athlete)|Bill Rodgers]], who had just won his third straight Boston Marathon, noticed that Ruiz could not recall many things that most runners know by heart, such as [[Interval training|intervals]] and splits.<ref name=EagleTribune/> Other observers noticed that Ruiz was not panting or coated in sweat, and her thighs were less lean and muscular than would be expected for a world-class runner. She later released stress-test results showing her resting heart rate as 76. Most female marathoners have a resting heart rate in the 50s or lower.<ref name=SI1/>
In addition, her time of 2:31:56 was an unusual improvement, more than 25 minutes ahead of her reported time in the [[New York City Marathon]] six months earlier. When asked by a reporter why she did not seem fatigued after the grueling race, she said, "I got up with a lot of energy this morning."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article2304891.ece | work=The Times | location=London | title=The top 50 sporting scandals | first=Patrick | last=Kidd | date=August 22, 2007 | accessdate=May 22, 2010 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080726212830/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article2304891.ece | archivedate = July 26, 2008}}</ref> Some female competitors thought it was odd that, when asked what she had noticed about the suburb of [[Wellesley, Massachusetts|Wellesley]] while running through it, she did not mention the students of [[Wellesley College]], who traditionally cheer loudly for the first female runners as they pass the campus. Most seriously, no other runners could recall seeing her. The eventual winner, Canadian [[Jacqueline Gareau]], was told that she was leading the race at the 18-mile mark, while [[Patti Catalano|Patti Lyons]] was told she was second at the 17-mile mark. Ruiz could not have passed either of them without being seen.<ref name=SI2/> Several spotters at checkpoints throughout the course also did not remember seeing her in the first group of women. In addition, she did not appear in any pictures or video footage.<ref name=MassMoments/>
Two [[Harvard University|Harvard]] students, John Faulkner and Sola Mahoney, recalled seeing Ruiz burst out of a crowd of spectators on [[Commonwealth Avenue, Boston|Commonwealth Avenue]], half a mile from the finish. Not long after that, freelance photographer Susan Morrow reported meeting her on the [[Rapid transit|subway]] during the New York Marathon and accompanying her from the subway to the race. She lost touch with Ruiz after that, but came forward when the news of Ruiz's dubious Boston win broke. According to Morrow, she met Ruiz on the subway and together they walked a distance to the finishing area, where Ruiz identified herself as an injured runner. She was escorted to a first aid station and volunteers marked her down as having completed the marathon, thus qualifying her for the Boston Marathon.<ref name=EagleTribune/>
New York Marathon officials launched an investigation and could not find any sign of Ruiz near the finish line. On April 25, based on this and other evidence, the games committee of the New York Marathon disqualified Ruiz from the 1979 race, saying she could not possibly have run the entire course.<ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times| accessdate= April 20, 2015| title= Miss Ruiz Deprived of New York Finish| first= Neil | last= Amdur | date = April 26, 1980 | url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1980/04/26/112076435.pdf }}</ref> Later that week, the Boston Athletic Association (BAA) disqualified Ruiz. While New York's action seemed to have automatically disqualified Ruiz from Boston as well, Boston officials wanted to do their own investigation before taking action.<ref name=EagleTribune/> Gareau was declared the female winner, with a time of 2:34:28—at the time, the fastest recorded for a woman in the Boston Marathon.<ref name="Seko">{{cite news |title=Seko Clocks A Boston Record |author= |first= |last= |authorlink= |authorlink2= |author2= |author3= |author4= |author5= |author6= |author7= |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bM8nAAAAIBAJ&sjid=120DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2802%2C4107090 |format= |agency=AP |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |publisher= |location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |pmid= |pmd= |bibcode= |doi= |id= |date=April 21, 1981 |page=19|at= |accessdate=January 13, 2011 |language= |trans-title=|quote= |ref=}}</ref> Lyons was moved up to second; her time of 2:35:08 was the fastest ever recorded for an American woman in a marathon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.runnersworld.com/rt-miscellaneous/rosie-ruiz-tries-steal-boston-marathon | title=Rosie Ruiz Tries To Steal the Boston Marathon |work=Running Times |date=July 1, 1980 |accessdate=April 20, 2015}}</ref>
On the Thursday after the Monday marathon, BAA arranged for Gareau to fly from her home in [[Canada]] to Boston, where BAA staged a finish line with 3,000 spectators at 2:34 PM so that photos could be taken with Gareau breaking the tape. Gareau was awarded a winner's medal at a [[press conference]] that Thursday.
== Aftermath == In 1982, Ruiz was arrested for embezzling $60,000 from a real estate company where she worked. She spent one week in jail and was sentenced to five years' probation.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xHgiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Aq0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1526,4781363&dq=rosie-ruiz+embezzle&hl=en | work=Arguss-Press | location=Owosso, Michigan | title=The Boston Marathon: One of Kind Event | first=Tony | last=Hornus | date=April 24, 1982| accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref><ref name="whatever"/> She then moved back to South Florida, where she was arrested in 1983 for her involvement in a cocaine deal. She was sentenced to three years' probation.<ref name = "whatever"/><ref>{{cite news| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19831119&id=Gv9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6u4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6791,1811064 | work=Spokesman-Review | location=Spokane, Washington | title=Rosie Ruiz arrested for cocaine dealing | agency=AP| date=November 19, 1983| accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> In April 1993, she was working in [[West Palm Beach]]<ref name="whatever">{{cite news| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19930419&id=a0xPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TAMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6311,5686888 | work=Toledo Blade | location= | title=Whatever happened to Rosie Ruiz? | agency=AP| date=April 19, 1993| accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> as a client representative for a medical laboratory company.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1998/Rosie-Ruiz-Says-She-ll-Run-Again/id-87582dc5d3da7b65adaad5a25ead3418 | work= | title=Rosie Ruiz Says She'll Run Again | agency=AP| date=April 20, 1998| accessdate=August 19, 2012}}</ref> As of 2000, she still maintained that she ran the entire 1980 Boston Marathon.<ref name=EagleTribune/>
